posts.com:
https://nypost.com/2022/01/14/ms-may-be-caused-by-kissing-disease-virus-scientists/
>A virus that infects more than 90% of adults and causes the “kissing disease” has been linked with the onset of multiple sclerosis in a new study.
>Researchers at Harvard University have added further evidence that the same virus which causes the illness mononucleosis, a k a “mono,” and commonly passed through saliva — hence “kissing disease” — may also encourage the development of multiple sclerosis, an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.
>The Epstein-Barr virus is a member of the herpes family, and one of the most common human viruses in the world. Some EBV infections may prompt fever, rash, sore throat, body aches and swollen glands — the conditions of mononucleosis.
>But new findings published in the journal Science on Thursday show that EBV may further lead to multiple sclerosis in some infected people.
>“The hypothesis that EBV causes MS has been investigated by our group and others for several years, but this is the first study providing compelling evidence of causality,” said the study’s senior author, Alberto Ascherio, a professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, in a press release.
>The study observed a group of 955 active service members in the US military who were diagnosed with MS. Comparing them to samples from a pool of 10 million service members, researchers saw that those found to be infected with the Epstein-Barr virus were 32-times more likely to have developed MS, while no other virus was shown to have the same effect.

posts.com:
>>28148281
Any business name, dealership or not, needs to be
- politically nuetral
- easy to remember or search up online, while still unique from other nearby/similar businesses
- not be totally weird or quirky
- carry no other baggage

So "Frank's Fast CARino's!" "Chevoy Autos" "Republic of Trucks" or "Adolf's Garage" may all seem like good ideas, but they violate one or some of these rules, and so people will give your business pre-assumptions, or judge them negatively before even visiting them, which is not good.

Be nuetral & easy to remember, yet distinguished. Also, it obviously needs to be an available business name in your area, for legal reasons.
Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dad was arrested when I was 10. My mom was abusive before, but the stress of becoming the sole provider ramped that shit up.
I learned some masculine things from the few men in my life -- neighbors taught me how to mow lawns, bring down trees, do some very minor craft work, while my uncle taught me to shave. But they were never people to aspire to be.
I struggled to want to embrace the good parts of my dad, even considering going into the same career field as him, but his really bad shit came to light right around the time I discovered my true passions and started to pursue them.
But this thread is about moms, so I'll pivot to that.
Despite all the abuse -- the actual gaslighting, the emotional manipulation, and the occasional hitting -- I was still the favorite child in the home. My sisters lament about how much easier I had it than them. One of my sister's has a scar across her chest from my mom scraping a lipstick tube against her after catching her with a Chuck Palahniuk book and calling her a disgusting whore.
My physical abuse ended right around the time I was 14 and officially became taller than my mom. The emotional shit was still there, though. I was highly risk averse, living essentially multiple lives between school, my friends, my sisters, my mom, and my grandma (she would watch us while my mom worked toward a masters degree while I was in high school). I did what I could to hide everything bad about myself, which made the really bad shit that inevitably occurred stand out dramatically.
I was scared of females, under the impression that my mom would judge harshly anyone I attempted to date. I later found out that wasn't the case, but when a girl sent me a bikini pic I completely panicked thinking any and all potential porn use as a minor would get my mom fired from her job and render us homeless (yes, this is what she told me when she saw porn in the browser history once).
1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28147616
While in high school, I realized how mediocre a cook my mom was. In hindsight, it was that she was too fucking busy with work, her school, 3 kids, and trying to work with attorneys to get my dad out of prison, but it made it that available food in the house was uncommon outside of dinners. I learned to cook so I could be able to eat more than the shitty cafeteria meals at lunch and the frozen, processed meals that awaited me for dinner. However, this was always a delicate practice because I was only guessing at what raw food was "planned" for meals, and my attempts to feed myself got me in trouble a number of times.
As implied with my "multiple lives" statement, I became quite good at lying convincingly and garnering pity from people. My mom never bought it, but peers, teachers, and others near me would never pay it a second thought if I was truthful.
I think one of the biggest ironies is that while it was a horrible, abusive situation, I have only recently been breaking the dependence on my mom for my life (I'm in my 30s). I relied on her for so fucking much in my 20s, when I truly shouldn't have. She was not a good advisor for school/work situations, she was far from a good confidant for my romantic life, and frankly even visits had some strange sense of tension and obligation, particularly around holidays.
I'm kind of rambling now, but it's really hard to say which was more impactful -- the abuse or the lack of masculine upbringing. My sisters claim I had it easier, but they're both married with children and I've never had much self confidence and ability to be vulnerable with people. They've taken great risks in their lives, and I'm the one who barely survived a suicide attempt.
I might can articulate specific issues better, but I think this incoherent mess should suffice for now.

I've found finding meaning to be completely meaningless. In my case, I became completely obsessed with raw pragmatism. Through daily repetition and practice. Every single time you think of them, think about how they're gone and how you're going to move on. Don't ever linger on them. As soon as you identify you're thinking of them, remind yourself they're gone and you need to let go and move on.

It could help to have everything written down on a piece of paper, like a mantra. Something you wrote to yourself to pull out and read whenever you think of them. What you write down on it will be unique to you and your experiences, but it should be little reminders to train your mind into letting go.

Just met with a girl whom I went to school with for 8 years, after not having seen each other for years. She appears just as cute as she was in school and we are going out soon. It’s great because ultimately we share a big portion of our childhood and youth development and saw each other grow up. I am really happy but I can’t seem to get rid of the lingering feeling of melancholia and the pain that years have passed without us being in contact. This 4 year gap of no contact stings a bit. She lost her innocence in most regards, not just sex. Even though she appears to be the same way she used to be in school, I know it’s impossible to not change. Her time passes the same way it does for me and it sets me unease, this heavy feeling in my chest and stomach…

She accumulated 4 years of experience without a single second of me being present and now I am suddenly hit with it. Maybe it’s even jealousy that other people got to make those experiences with her. Everything might be close to how it used to be, but it’s not going to be the same. I don’t even know why I am feeling so down, I was hoping to get the answer while writing this post, but I guess it just sort of turns out to be an agglomeration of incoherent thoughts passing my mind.

I think in the end it boils down to nostalgia/melancholia and even envy…

posts.com:
>>28148015
Depends, their are some good ones and their are some bad ones. Generally I support unions given the worker power imbalance today, but I've also seen some really corrupt ones as well.

Like the union at Safeway grocery store, for years they protected workers and made things better. But then a major split happened and the union only started protecting the old members and any new members got the new plan with the new benefits, which was nothing compared to the old members. As time passes the old members slowly left and the new members grew effectively destroying the union. Only good that $14 dues gave new members was they couldn't fire you instantly as the paper work slowed everything down allowing you to look for another job, were as the old members got a amazing plan with pension. I spent hours and hours on the phone between the union and the company trying to get the health care everyone said I had. Union wouldn't push the matter till I got a copy of my health benefits contact as because of the split they didn't know which plan I had, and the company kept saying they'd get me a copy and then would leave me on the phone till the system timed out and hung up after 3 hours again and again. The result was I effectively never got the health care which destroyed my saving potential for some of my prime savings years as I paid out of pocket for everything, that was ~$12,000 a year I could have put to an IRA in my early 20s.

Compare that to the Teacher Union my Dad has which actually give a shit and is trying to fix the horrible working conditions and the states education, not just for the members but also the public good. I think paying them my $14 dues would have been a far better investment if at the very least to help the community I live in.

Just read philosophy. The best lessons anybody in their relative youth can learn are basic critical thinking and logical reasoning -learning how to question the world around you. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

>>28112537
HPV is incurable, and can sometimes lead to cancer; if you get a strain which causes warts, the individual warts can be treated, but this is painful, and they will keep popping up for several years at least.

HIV is incurable; it is usually treatable, but the drugs are very expensive and can have nasty side effects; you need to take them for life. Occasionally the drugs stop working and people die.

Herpes is incurable, and infects you for life - outbreaks become less frequent with time, but they never stop; herpes simplex 2 is excruciatingly painful; there are drugs that will help treat an outbreak, but you can't take them constantly.

Chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea are usually treatable with antibiotics, but antibiotic-resistant strains of gonorrhoea and syphilis are becoming steadily more common. Note that syphilis can cause insanity or death if it isn't treated, which happens more often than you'd think, because the initial symptoms disappear after a month or two, then it comes back with a vengeance years later, having quietly damaged your central nervous system in the mean time.

Hepatitis is untreatable - you will probably eventually recover from it after several years, but you'll be very sick indeed while you're waiting; it does sometimes kill.

There are other types of bacterial infection that you can pick up from sex; these are generally treatable with antibiotics.

What does normal mean in this context? Common? I don't think that's the right question. I think what really matters is if it's healthy for you, them and the relationship.

With that said, sometimes it's worth picking your battles. If it's something insignificant you don't care about/that doesn't matter but they're going to make a mountain out of a mole hill, sometimes it's worth just smiling and nodding. In those situations it isn't worth a fight.

You just have to learn how to weigh up whether conflict is healthy or not in a given situation.

If you don't have access to a pro bono, community or cheap lawyer in your area that you can afford, then you're SOL.

You can try contacting the tenants association in your area and see what kinds of mediation services they offer.

posts.name: Anonymous

Step 1. Type this in to your search engine of choice

>> Piano lessons [enter your suburb/borough], London.

Step 2. Look through the results. You make need to check through multiple pages

Step 3. Pick up your phone and call some of the schools and tutors you find interesting. Get information about pricing and availability

Step 4. Go on gumtree, select your area from the options and into search type in

>> Piano lessons

Step 5. Browse the private tutors

Step 6. Decide who you want to go with.

Step 7. Call them and make a standing appointment

Step 8. Pay your semester

Step 9. Attend your lessons

That's it.

It's called self worth, anon. Get some. Have some. Value yourself, value your time, value your capability, value your potential, and doing so will put these situations in their proper perspective, rather than the false sense of their value and consequence that you find yourself assigning to them. You have to know that you are worth more, and are destined for more, than what these situations have in store for you. This will motivate you to attain what you deserve. All you have to do is believe that you can do something better, and then go and do it, plan for it if you need time to prepare, but clearly set your sights on it and make that your compass to guide your mind instead. Don't think in terms of what consequences may arise if you do take initiative, adopt the mindest to work towards that which you stand to gain by taking those risks. You can think of endless reasons not to do something, but enough valid and meaningful reasons TO do something make them all irrelevant, if it's worth it to you.
